title: How to Dispose of Halogen Light Bulbs

steps.headline: Wrap your halogen bulbs in their original packaging before recycling.
steps.description: Light bulbs have very thin glass, and can break inside of a recycling can or while they are being processed. To prevent broken glass, wrap your halogen bulbs in their original packaging or another soft material, like cardboard or newspaper. Tip: Use recyclable materials to wrap your bulbs if you will be recycling them.

steps.headline: Put the bulbs in your recycling bin if it is legal to.
steps.description: If your county or city has a recycling program, check their website or call their customer service representative to see if you can dispose of your halogen bulbs in the recycling. If you can, put them in your normal recycling bin, not the glass one. Halogen bulbs do not contain harmful chemicals, so they can be recycled safely.

steps.headline: Drop off your bulbs at a recycling center if necessary.
steps.description:
If you don’t have a curbside program, some counties or cities have recycling centers that you can take your recycling to. Search local recycling centers and see if they will take halogen bulbs from you. Use search terms like, “recycling centers near me.”
Be sure to double check whether or not the recycling center will accept halogen bulbs by checking their website or calling them. Some recycling centers have a fee for dropping off materials.

steps.headline: Contact light bulb companies to see if they have mail back programs.
steps.description: Some environmental and light bulb companies have programs where you can ship light bulbs back to them for recycling. Call light bulb manufacturers near you to ask about their programs and if you will need to pay for shipping. Make sure you pad your package well so that your bulbs don’t break in transit. Some companies will send you a specific box to put your halogen bulbs in. Make sure to use their box, as it probably comes with prepaid shipping.

methods.name: Putting Halogen Bulbs in the Garbage

steps.headline: Wrap your halogen bulbs in a plastic bag before throwing them away.
steps.description: Halogen bulbs don’t contain harsh chemicals, but they can break inside a garbage can. Put your halogen bulbs in a plastic bag or wrap them in bubble wrap to keep any sharp glass shards contained. Broken glass can harm sanitation workers as they do their jobs.

steps.headline: Put your bulbs in the garbage if you don’t have a recycling program.
steps.description: Since halogen bulbs are non-toxic, you can throw them away with your regular trash if you don’t have a recycling program, or if your recycling program won’t accept them.Tip: Double check with your local laws to make sure putting light bulbs in the garbage is legal.

steps.headline: Take your light bulbs to your local dump.
steps.description: If you have a lot of halogen bulbs or you are worried about broken glass in your trash can, you can take them to your local dump for disposal. Some dumps charge a fee for dropping off materials, so make sure you double check how much you will be paying.
